content:
(Note: This stream was split from Bimodules vs Spans: Puzzle 1.)

Puzzle 2: What’s a module of a monoid object in Setop\mathsf{Set^{op}}Setop?

We're looking for an object, i.e. set, XXX and a monoid object AAA together with an action
{}
α:A×X→X.\alpha: A\times X\to X.α:A×X→X.

Attempt #1

I think this action should be
{}
eval:[X,X]×X→X,eval:(f,x)↦f(x).\sout{\mathsf{eval}: [X,X]\times X\to X,\quad \mathsf{eval}: (f,x) \mapsto f(x).}eval:[X,X]×X→X,eval:(f,x)↦f(x).​
{}
This is true for every set XXX in Setop\mathsf{Set^{op}}Setop so every set XXX is an End(X)\mathsf{End}(X)End(X)-module.

Attempt #2: After looking at Puzzle #3

Referring to Attempt #3 in Puzzle #1, there are actually two kinds of modules in Setop\mathsf{Set^{op}}Setop corresponding to the two types of monoid objects.
{}
1. A left End(X)\mathsf{End}(X)End(X)-module is a set XXX and an action αL:End(X)×X→X.\sout{\alpha_L : \mathsf{End}(X)\times X\to X.}αL​:End(X)×X→X.​
2. A right End(X)\mathsf{End}(X)End(X)-module is a set XXX and an action αR:Endop(X)×X→X.\sout{\alpha_R : \mathsf{End^{op}}(X)\times X\to X.}αR​:Endop(X)×X→X.​

{}
In both cases, the action is function evaluation.

I see my mistake. My intuition wasn't too bad, but as often the case, I missed the mark :bow_and_arrow: :bulls_eye:

My action is too big. It contains all possible actions. The set AAA is important. Hookoodanode :shrug:

The way I should probably think of it is the action
{}
α:A×X→X\sout{\alpha: A\times X\to X}α:A×X→X​
{}
is more like a map
{}
α:A→End(X).\sout{\alpha: A\to\mathsf{End}(X).}α:A→End(X).​
{}
For each a∈Aa\in Aa∈A, we get an endofunction α(a,−):X→X.\sout{\alpha(a,-): X\to X.}α(a,−):X→X.​

Attempt #3

Now that I see it, is is almost embarassing. The answer is pretty much embedded in the puzzle.

An AAA-module XXX of a monoid object AAA in Setop\mathsf{Set^{op}}Setop is a set XXX and a function
{}
α:A×X→X.\sout{\alpha: A\times X\to X.}α:A×X→X.​

:face_palm:

As mentioned in my solution to Puzzle 3, an even better solution to Puzzle 2 is the following:

A left AAA-module XXX of a monoid object AAA in Setop\mathsf{Set^{op}}Setop is a span
Left AAA-Module

A right BBB-module XXX of a monoid object BBB in Setop\mathsf{Set^{op}}Setop is a span
Right BBB-module

An (A,B)(A,B)(A,B)-module XXX of monoid objects A,BA,BA,B in Setop\mathsf{Set^{op}}Setop is a span

which can be seen as the composition of left and right modules, where a left AAA-module is a (A,∗)(A,*)(A,∗)-bimodule and a right AAA-module is a (∗,B)(*,B)(∗,B)-bimodule.

Eric Forgy said:

Attempt #3

Now that I see it, is is almost embarassing. The answer is pretty much embedded in the puzzle.

An AAA-module XXX of a monoid object AAA in Setop\mathsf{Set^{op}}Setop is a set XXX and a function
{}
α:A×X→X.\alpha: A\times X\to X.α:A×X→X.

No, that's not true. An action of a monoid object AAA in Set\mathsf{Set}Set is a set XXX and a function α:A×X→X\alpha: A\times X\to Xα:A×X→X such that 2 equations hold (which I'm too lazy to write now). But I'm asking about an action of a monoid object in Setop\mathsf{Set}^{\rm{op}}Setop!

So you have to turn around an arrow in your answer, and you need to take those 2 equations into account.

But there are also other surprises, which show up when you think a bit harder about this using Puzzle 1.

Thank you :pray:

I'll keep at this. I'm hoping this will pay off :sweat_smile:
The ultimate answer here is incredibly simple, but it takes some thought to get it.

Ok. An action
{}
α:A×X→X\alpha: A\times X\to Xα:A×X→X
{}
in Setop\mathsf{Set^{op}}Setop is a function X→A×XX\to A\times XX→A×X :thinking:
Is that right at least? Or do I need to swap products too, i.e. X→A⊔XX\to A\sqcup XX→A⊔X?

All these puzzles are taking place in the category Setop\mathsf{Set}^{\mathrm{op}}Setop where the monoidal structure is ×\times×, defined by

X×Y={(x,y):x∈X,y∈Y}X \times Y = \{(x,y): x \in X, y \in Y\}X×Y={(x,y):x∈X,y∈Y}
I just answered your question. I hope you see how I answered it.
I didn't want to just say "yes" or "no"... I wanted to remind you of what you need to know.
I obviously have zero intuition when it comes to op\mathsf{op}op stuff.
Well, so what's the answer to your question "Is that right at least?"
Yes? Or no?

John Baez said:

All these puzzles are taking place in the category Setop\mathsf{Set}^{\mathrm{op}}Setop where the monoidal structure is ×\times×, defined by

X×Y={(x,y):x∈X,y∈Y}X \times Y = \{(x,y): x \in X, y \in Y\}X×Y={(x,y):x∈X,y∈Y}

You have it now in the display line, but without that, it's potentially confusing because the cartesian product ×\times× in Setop\mathsf{Set^{op}}Setop corresponds to the coproduct in Set\mathsf{Set}Set.

I don't know.

X×YX\times YX×Y is a diagram and op\mathsf{op}op 'ing it gives a different diagram so I am confused.

An action
{}
α:A×X→X\alpha: A\times X\to Xα:A×X→X
{}
in Setop\mathsf{Set^{op}}Setop is also a diagram. Since an arrow S→TS\to TS→T in Setop\mathsf{Set^{op}}Setop is an arrow T→ST\to ST→S in Set\mathsf{Set}Set, there seems to be just enough ambiguity for me to get confused whether that should be X→A×XX\to A\times XX→A×X or X→A⊔XX\to A\sqcup XX→A⊔X in Set\mathsf{Set}Set :pensive:

Todd Trimble said:

John Baez said:

All these puzzles are taking place in the category Setop\mathsf{Set}^{\mathrm{op}}Setop where the monoidal structure is ×\times×, defined by

X×Y={(x,y):x∈X,y∈Y}X \times Y = \{(x,y): x \in X, y \in Y\}X×Y={(x,y):x∈X,y∈Y}

You have it now in the display line, but without that, it's potentially confusing because the cartesian product ×\times× in Setop\mathsf{Set^{op}}Setop corresponds to the coproduct in Set\mathsf{Set}Set.

Yeah! So let's just all agree that we're using the product in Set to give Setop\mathsf{Set}^{\rm op}Setop a monoidal structure which we are going to call ×\times×.
It's confusing no matter what you call it, so let's just call it ×\times×.

Eric Forgy said:

I don't know.

X×YX\times YX×Y is a diagram and op\mathsf{op}op 'ing it gives a different diagram so I am confused.

I said that that X×YX\times YX×Y is our notation for the set {(x,y):x∈X,y∈Y}\{(x,y) : x \in X , y \in Y\}{(x,y):x∈X,y∈Y}. I wrote out that crud to emphasize that in these puzzles, that's what I always mean by X×YX \times YX×Y. Okay?
I said it all before:

John Baez said:

All these puzzles are taking place in the category Setop\mathsf{Set}^{\mathrm{op}}Setop where the monoidal structure is ×\times×, defined by

X×Y={(x,y):x∈X,y∈Y}X \times Y = \{(x,y): x \in X, y \in Y\}X×Y={(x,y):x∈X,y∈Y}

So I told you what our monoidal category is:

A morphism from XXX to YYY is a function f:Y→Xf: Y \to Xf:Y→X, and the tensor product is ×\times× as defined above!
Once you know that, you know (in theory) what a monoid object is, in this monoidal category.
Puzzle 1 was to figure out all possible monoid objects in this monoidal category.
Puzzle 2, which relies heavily on puzzle 1, is to figure out all actions of monoid object in this monoidal category.
So what's an action of a monoid object in this monoidal category?

Hold on...

I need to get my bearings before I can answer basic questions.

(You're talking to someone who has never really thought much about and has never worked with op\mathsf{op}op.)

In Set\mathsf{Set}Set we have a product ×\times× and a coproduct ⊔.\sqcup.⊔. The product ×\times× is a universal diagram (a span actually) and the coproduct is a universal cospan. An object X×YX\times YX×Y can be written in terms of elements of XXX and YYY as
{}
X×Y={(x,y):x∈X,y∈Y}.X\times Y = \{(x,y) : x\in X, y\in Y\}.X×Y={(x,y):x∈X,y∈Y}.
{}
This object exists in both Set\mathsf{Set}Set and Setop,\mathsf{Set^{op}},Setop, but it is not the product of XXX and YYY in Setop\mathsf{Set^{op}}Setop. It is actually their coproduct because a universal span in Set\mathsf{Set}Set is a universal cospan in Setop.\mathsf{Set^{op}}.Setop. More generally, a limit in Set\mathsf{Set}Set is a colimit in Setop\mathsf{Set^{op}}Setop and vise versa.

So, getting back to the puzzle, an action
{}
α:A×X→X\alpha: A\times X\to Xα:A×X→X
{}
in Setop\mathsf{Set^{op}}Setop is a morphism from the object A×XA\times XA×X to the object X,X,X, which corresponds to a function
{}
αop:X→A×X\alpha^\mathsf{op}: X\to A\times Xαop:X→A×X
{}
from the object XXX to the object A×X.A\times X.A×X.
{}
The only function I can think of would pick an element a∈Aa\in Aa∈A and we can write
{}
αop=a:X→A×X,x↦(a,x).\sout{\alpha^\mathsf{op} = a: X\to A\times X,\quad x\mapsto (a,x)}.αop=a:X→A×X,x↦(a,x)​.

This feels a little weird, but if we have a function
{}
α:A×X→X\alpha: A\times X\to Xα:A×X→X
{}
and choose an element a∈Aa\in Aa∈A, we can define a function
{}
αop:X→A×X,x↦(a,α(a,x)).\alpha^\mathsf{op}: X\to A\times X,\quad x\mapsto (a,\alpha(a,x)).αop:X→A×X,x↦(a,α(a,x)).
I don't know what you're doing. I suggest you start by writing down the definition of a module in the monoidal category I so painstakingly specified.
Then, after you've written down the definition, including the two equations that need to hold, you could seek to analyze what a module in that monoidal category actually amounts to.

Eric Forgy said:

This feels a little weird, but if we have a function
{}
α:A×X→X\alpha: A\times X\to Xα:A×X→X

Since α\alphaα is a morphism in Setop\mathrm{Set}^\mathrm{op}Setop , this is technically the opposite of a function. Not sure if this will help you, but it might be easier to think about the honest-to-goodness functions X→A×XX \rightarrow A \times XX→A×X of which there are many. Generally, crazy stuff could happen in both the AAA part and in the XXX part of A×XA \times XA×X, but you want to find the one(s) that play(s) well with the definition of a module when you op it/them.

John Baez said:

I don't know what you're doing. I suggest you start by writing down the definition of a module in the monoidal category I so painstakingly specified.

This is what I'm trying to do :pensive:

From the nLab:

Definition

Let (V,⊗,I)(\mathcal{V}, \otimes, I)(V,⊗,I) be a [[monoidal category]] and AAA a [[monoid object]] in V\mathcal{V}V, hence an object A∈VA \in \mathcal{V}A∈V equipped with a multiplication morphism

⋅:A⊗A→A\cdot : A \otimes A \to A⋅:A⊗A→A

and a unit element

e:I→Ae : I \to Ae:I→A

satisfying the [[associativity law]] and the [[unit law]].

Definition

A (left) module over AAA in (V,⊗,I)(\mathcal{V}, \otimes, I)(V,⊗,I) is

  • an [[object]] N∈VN \in \mathcal{V}N∈V

  • equipped with a morphism

λ:A⊗N→N\lambda : A \otimes N \to Nλ:A⊗N→N

in V\mathcal{V}V

such that this satisfies the axioms of an [[action]], in that the following are [[commuting diagrams]] in V\mathcal{V}V:

Puzzle 1 was about sorting out the monoid objects and I think I got that.

Puzzle 2 is defining the module. Looking at the definition above, the thing I need is an action
{}
α:A×X→X.\alpha: A\times X\to X.α:A×X→X.
{}

I was trying to define the action, but obviously failing :pensive:

Jason Erbele said:

Eric Forgy said:

This feels a little weird, but if we have a function
{}
α:A×X→X\alpha: A\times X\to Xα:A×X→X

Since α\alphaα is a morphism in Setop\mathrm{Set}^\mathrm{op}Setop , this is technically the opposite of a function. Not sure if this will help you, but it might be easier to think about the honest-to-goodness functions X→A×XX \rightarrow A \times XX→A×X of which there are many. Generally, crazy stuff could happen in both the AAA part and in the XXX part of A×XA \times XA×X, but you want to find the one(s) that play(s) well with the definition of a module when you op it/them.

Thanks Jason. I was missing the "usual equations" :face_palm:

I understood the monoid object by looking at the opposite functions in Set.\mathsf{Set}.Set. To understand an action in Setop\mathsf{Set^{op}}Setop, I was trying to look at the opposite function X→A×XX\to A\times XX→A×X, but I failed to consider the "usual equations". I'll keep trying...

Remember, in an ordinary action of an ordinary monoid A on a set X we demand two equations, the left unit law

1x = x

and associativity

a(bx) = (ab)x

You should be familiar with these in from the definition of a module, which is an action of a monoid object in (Vect,⊗)(\mathsf{Vect}, \otimes) (Vect,⊗) on an object in (Vect,⊗)(\mathsf{Vect}, \otimes) (Vect,⊗).

So we abstract these and write these as commutative diagrams to get the definition of a monoid object in any monoidal category on any object of that category.

The point of Puzzle 2 is to see what these imply in our example (Setop,×)(\mathsf{Set}^{\rm op}, \times)(Setop,×).

I don't think you ever really solved Puzzle 1, which is to take the axioms for a monoid object and see what they imply in (Setop,×)(\mathsf{Set}^{\rm op}, \times)(Setop,×). In my own answer I sketched the miracle that happens there: it turns out that for any set there's exactly one way to make it into a monoid object in (Setop,×)(\mathsf{Set}^{\rm op}, \times)(Setop,×). To prove this you need to use the equations in the definition of monoid object.

A similar miracle happens in Puzzle 2, and the argument is similar.

Quick recap of Puzzle 1...

A monoid object in Setop\mathsf{Set^{op}}Setop is, first of all, a set (what else could it be?) AAA. But we also need a multiplication
{}
μ:A×A→A\mu: A\times A\to Aμ:A×A→A
{}
and a unit
{}
η:∗→A\eta:*\to Aη:∗→A
{}
satisfying equations.

To understand μ\muμ, you can look at the opposite function A→A×AA\to A\times AA→A×A. This is the diagonal map a↦(a,a)∈A×A.a\mapsto (a,a)\in A\times A.a↦(a,a)∈A×A.

To understand η\etaη, you can look at the opposite function A→∗A\to *A→∗. This just sends every element of AAA to the one element in ∗.*.∗.

A quick doodle confirms the equations are satisfied.

For Puzzle 2...

A (left) AAA-module is a set XXX, a monoid object AAA and an action
{}
α:A×X→X\alpha: A\times X\to Xα:A×X→X
{}
satisfying equations.

To understand α\alphaα, you can look at the opposite function X→A×X.X\to A\times X.X→A×X. This is a function that for a given a∈Aa\in Aa∈A maps x↦(a,x).x\mapsto (a,x).x↦(a,x).

A quick doodle confirms the equations are satisfied.

Here is the doodle:

We need to check
{}
x↦αop(a,x)↦μop×id(a,a,x)x\overset{\alpha^\mathsf{op}}{\mapsto} (a,x)\overset{\mu^\mathsf{op}\times\mathsf{id}}{\mapsto} (a,a,x)x↦αop​(a,x)↦μop×id​(a,a,x)
{}
is the same as
{}
x↦αop(a,x)↦id×αop(a,a,x).x\overset{\alpha^\mathsf{op}}{\mapsto} (a,x)\overset{\mathsf{id}\times \alpha^\mathsf{op}}{\mapsto} (a,a,x).x↦αop​(a,x)↦id×αop​(a,a,x).
{}
Check :check_mark:

We also need to check
{}
x↦(∙,x)x\mapsto (\bullet,x)x↦(∙,x)
{}
is the same as
{}
x↦αop(a,x)↦ηop×id(∙,x).x\overset{\alpha^\mathsf{op}}{\mapsto} (a,x) \overset{\eta^\mathsf{op}\times\mathsf{id}}{\mapsto} (\bullet,x).x↦αop​(a,x)↦ηop×id​(∙,x).
{}
Check :check_mark:
Will any other way of choosing α\alphaα satisfy these equations?
Maybe? :sweat_smile:
Actually, no. I don't think so.

This was my first thought, but I striked it out above and generalized to
{}
αop:x↦(a,αop(a,x))\alpha^\mathsf{op}: x\mapsto (a,\alpha^\mathsf{op}(a,x))αop:x↦(a,αop(a,x))
{}
but then this didn't satisfy the unit equations.
If there is another way, can you find it? If there isn't, can you prove that there is no other way of choosing α\alphaα to satisfy these equations?
Also, because the diagonal map, there can only be one chosen a∈Aa\in Aa∈A. We have freedom which aaa we choose, but once its chosen, that is your α.\alpha.α.
Sure. You have a collection of α\alphaα s indexed by your choice of a∈Aa \in Aa∈A, but that's all one way of choosing α\alphaα. :upside_down:

I started with a more general
{}
x↦αop(a,x′)↦μop×id(a,a,x′)x\overset{\alpha^\mathsf{op}}{\mapsto} (a,x')\overset{\mu^\mathsf{op}\times\mathsf{id}}{\mapsto} (a,a,x')x↦αop​(a,x′)↦μop×id​(a,a,x′)
{}
x↦αop(a,x′)↦id×αop(a,a,x′′),x\overset{\alpha^\mathsf{op}}{\mapsto} (a,x')\overset{\mathsf{id}\times \alpha^\mathsf{op}}{\mapsto} (a,a,x''),x↦αop​(a,x′)↦id×αop​(a,a,x′′),
{}
but that only commutes if αop(x)=(a,x).\alpha^\mathsf{op}(x) = (a,x).αop(x)=(a,x).

I'm just going to re-state this:
Jason Erbele said:

Generally, crazy stuff could happen in both the AAA part and in the XXX part of A×XA \times XA×X, but you want to find the one(s) that play(s) well with the definition of a module when you op it/them.

Sorry, I'm feeling dense. Did I miss something or is what I said correct? :sweat_smile:

To understand an action α:A×X→X\alpha: A\times X\to Xα:A×X→X in Setop\mathsf{Set^{op}}Setop, we can look at the opposite function αop:X→A×X\alpha^\mathsf{op}: X\to A\times Xαop:X→A×X in Set\mathsf{Set}Set and this function is x↦(a,x)x\mapsto (a,x)x↦(a,x), so α\alphaα in Setop\mathsf{Set^{op}}Setop is the opposite of this function. Right?

You're looking for an action α:A×X→X\alpha: A \times X \rightarrow Xα:A×X→X. This is essentially the same as a function from XXX to A×XA \times XA×X. I think you've got that point. But the point I'm making in the bit I quoted is that you can have a function f:{x,y,z}→{a,b,c}×{x,y,z}f: \{x,y,z\} \rightarrow \{a,b,c\} \times \{x,y,z\}f:{x,y,z}→{a,b,c}×{x,y,z} that, let's say, maps xxx to (a,x)(a,x)(a,x), maps yyy to (c,z)(c,z)(c,z), and maps zzz to (a,z)(a,z)(a,z). So a function in general can have crazy stuff going on in both the AAA and XXX parts.
Right. That is why it is important to check "the equations" :blush:

Now that particular function, when opped, will not be (an instance of) the action you are looking for, and it looks like see why. But the point is that it seems you are ignoring a huge swath of potential actions.

Oh. Ok. Thanks. I was too dense to realize that is what you meant :sweat_smile:

I'll think some more :pray:

If you take the special case of A=XA = XA=X, you have already identified an important morphism (in puzzle 1) that looks like A×X→XA \times X \rightarrow XA×X→X. Have you checked the action equations on that one?
I think I see what you mean. Instead of choosing an element a∈Aa\in Aa∈A, we want a function f:X→A.f:X\to A.f:X→A.
Will something like that always work? Is there a way to express what you were doing with a∈Aa \in Aa∈A as a special case of this new attempt?

x↦αop(f(x),x)↦μop×id(f(x),f(x),x)x\overset{\alpha^\mathsf{op}}{\mapsto} (f(x),x)\overset{\mu^\mathsf{op}\times\mathsf{id}}{\mapsto} (f(x),f(x),x)x↦αop​(f(x),x)↦μop×id​(f(x),f(x),x)
{}
x↦αop(f(x),x)↦id×αop(f(x),f(x),x).x\overset{\alpha^\mathsf{op}}{\mapsto} (f(x),x)\overset{\mathsf{id}\times \alpha^\mathsf{op}}{\mapsto} (f(x),f(x),x).x↦αop​(f(x),x)↦id×αop​(f(x),f(x),x).

Check :check_mark:

x↦(∙,x)x\mapsto (\bullet,x)x↦(∙,x)
{}
x↦αop(f(x),x)↦ηop×id(∙,x).x\overset{\alpha^\mathsf{op}}{\mapsto} (f(x),x) \overset{\eta^\mathsf{op}\times\mathsf{id}}{\mapsto} (\bullet,x).x↦αop​(f(x),x)↦ηop×id​(∙,x).

Check :check_mark:

Jason Erbele said:

Will something like that always work? Is there a way to express what you were doing with a∈Aa \in Aa∈A as a special case of this new attempt?

What I had before was equivalent to having just one f:X→Af:X\to Af:X→A that sends every element of XXX to the element a∈A.a\in A.a∈A.
Now for the big question: Is there any other way that you could pick an action?

Of course not!

(I wish I was that confident :sweat_smile: But I don't think so :blush: )
That seems to be the most general αop\alpha^\mathsf{op}αop that will satisfy the conditions.

You've played with what I referred to as "craziness" that can happen in the AAA part of X→A×XX \rightarrow A \times XX→A×X with that f:X→Af : X \rightarrow Af:X→A. Where else did I mention "craziness" could happen in a function X→A×XX \rightarrow A \times XX→A×X ?

Ok ok :blush:

Back to the drawing board. Thank you :raised_hands:

There is one step in the equations I'm not sure about. There is an arrow I⊗N→NI\otimes N\to NI⊗N→N, which gets reversed to X→∗×XX\to *\times XX→∗×X. I thought this should be x↦(∙,x)x\mapsto (\bullet, x)x↦(∙,x) with no craziness, but if that is the case, then there can not be any craziness in the XXX part of X→A×XX\to A\times XX→A×X :thinking:

So if αop\alpha^\mathsf{op}αop involved both a function f:X→Af:X\to Af:X→A and a function g:X→Xg:X\to Xg:X→X with
{}
α:x↦(f(x),g(x))\alpha: x\mapsto (f(x),g(x))α:x↦(f(x),g(x))
{}
then I need that identity equation to be x↦(∙,g(x))x\mapsto (\bullet,g(x))x↦(∙,g(x)) :thinking:

x↦αop(f(x),g(x))↦μop×id(f(x),f(x),g(x))x\overset{\alpha^\mathsf{op}}{\mapsto} (f(x),g(x))\overset{\mu^\mathsf{op}\times\mathsf{id}}{\mapsto} (f(x),f(x),g(x))x↦αop​(f(x),g(x))↦μop×id​(f(x),f(x),g(x))
{}
x↦αop(f(x),g(x))↦id×αop(f(x),f(x),g(x)).x\overset{\alpha^\mathsf{op}}{\mapsto} (f(x),g(x))\overset{\mathsf{id}\times \alpha^\mathsf{op}}{\mapsto} (f(x),f(x),g(x)).x↦αop​(f(x),g(x))↦id×αop​(f(x),f(x),g(x)).

Check :check_mark:

x↦(∙,x)x\mapsto (\bullet,x)x↦(∙,x)
{}
x↦αop(f(x),g(x))↦ηop×id(∙,g(x)).x\overset{\alpha^\mathsf{op}}{\mapsto} (f(x),g(x)) \overset{\eta^\mathsf{op}\times\mathsf{id}}{\mapsto} (\bullet,g(x)).x↦αop​(f(x),g(x))↦ηop×id​(∙,g(x)).

Doesn't check :x:
The only way to make it check is if the map X→∗×XX\to *\times XX→∗×X knows about ggg somehow :thinking:
So what can you conclude about what happens in the XXX part?

I don't think X→∗×XX\to *\times XX→∗×X can know about ggg, so the XXX part cannot vary and we have
{}

Yes. A lot of the way I learn things is a random walk. Try. Fail. Try again. This goes for everything in life. Not just mathematics. So here is

Atempt #4
{}

Puzzle 2: What’s a module of a monoid object in Setop\mathsf{Set^{op}}Setop?

{}
A left AAA-module XXX of a monoid object AAA in Setop\mathsf{Set^{op}}Setop is a function f:X→A.f:X\to A.f:X→A.

We see this by considering the definition of a module. A module in Setop\mathsf{Set^{op}}Setop is a set XXX and a monoid object AAA together with an action
{}
α:A×X→X\alpha: A\times X\to Xα:A×X→X
{}
satisfying some conditions.

This action can be understood by looking at the opposite function
{}
αop:X→A×X\alpha^\mathsf{op}: X\to A\times Xαop:X→A×X
{}
in Set.\mathsf{Set}.Set. Such a function is determined by a function f:X→Af:X\to Af:X→A so that αop\alpha^\mathsf{op}αop can be given explicitly in terms of fff (and μop\mu^\mathsf{op}μop) via
{}
αop=(f×idX)∘μop,\alpha^\mathsf{op} = (f\times\mathsf{id}_X)\circ\mu^\mathsf{op},αop=(f×idX​)∘μop,
{}
where μop\mu^\mathsf{op}μop is the diagonal map X→X×X.X\to X\times X.X→X×X.
The opposite of αop\alpha^\mathsf{op}αop in Setop\mathsf{Set^{op}}Setop is an action A×X→X.A\times X\to X.A×X→X.

Atempt #4
{}

Puzzle 2: What’s a module of a monoid object in Setop\mathsf{Set^{op}}Setop?

{}
A left AAA-module XXX of a monoid object AAA in Setop\mathsf{Set^{op}}Setop is a function f:X→A.f:X\to A.f:X→A.

But then every function corresponds to a span, so another answer is:

A left AAA-module XXX of a monoid object AAA in Setop\mathsf{Set^{op}}Setop is a span X←X→A.X\leftarrow X\rightarrow A.X←X→A.

I need to check, but I think a safe guess is that a right BBB-module is a span
{}
B←X→XB\leftarrow X\rightarrow XB←X→X
{}
and an (A,B)(A,B)(A,B)-bimodule is the composition of the two, i.e.
{}
B←X→AB\leftarrow X\rightarrow AB←X→A
{}
and the composition of an (A,B)(A,B)(A,B)-bimodule XXX with a (B,C)(B,C)(B,C)-bimodule YYY is the composition of the two spans
{}
C←Y×BX→A.C\leftarrow Y\times_B X\rightarrow A.C←Y×B​X→A.
{}
If this guess isn't correct, then something very similar looking to this should be correct (but I think this is correct).

I'm fairly confident about this, because:
{}

  • A left AAA-module should be equivalent to an (A,∗)(A,*)(A,∗)-bimodule
  • A right BBB-module should be equivalent to a (∗,B)(*,B)(∗,B)-bimodule
A (∗,∗)(,)(∗,∗)-bimodule is a monoid object :blush:

Eric Forgy said:

But then every function corresponds to a span, so another answer is:

A left AAA-module XXX of a monoid object AAA in Setop\mathsf{Set^{op}}Setop is a span X←X→A.X\leftarrow X\rightarrow A.X←X→A.

I don't believe that. I believe a left AAA-module XXX of a monoid object AAA in Setop\mathsf{Set^{op}}Setop is the same as a span of the form

X←1X→fAX \stackrel{1}{\leftarrow} X\stackrel{f}{\rightarrow} AX←1X→fA
In other words, the morphism from XXX to itself in this span must be the identity.
Such a span is a long-winded way of talking about a function f:X→Af: X \to Af:X→A, so I'd say the answer is "a function from XXX to AAA".
Yes. That is what I meant. That is how you turn a function into a span (I've seen it denoted f∗f_*f∗​).
Okay, good. Please try to say what you mean... if you say "a span X←X→AX \leftarrow X \to AX←X→A", that means an arbitrary span of this form.
Ok. I still need to learn when I need to be explicit and when not. It seems you guys are always leaving off stuff like that :sweat_smile:

We leave out unimportant things. You're leaving out crucial things. It's like I asked "what's 2+2" and you said "an even number", and then it turns out you meant 4. Part of my goal in this discussion is to try to teach you to communicate with mathematicians. This involves a higher level of precision.

Maybe part of the problem is this: when reviewing material one can leave out details while making it clear details are being left out, so the person reading it can ask questions. But when answering puzzles, or proving theorems (which is basically the same thing), one can't leave out details that make the difference between truth and falsity.
Ok. Thank you :pray:

I think it does help to think of modules in Setop\mathsf{Set^{op}}Setop as spans though since:

  • An (A,B)(A,B)(A,B)-bimodule is a span
  • A left AAA-module is quivalent to an (A,∗)(A,*)(A,∗)-bimodule, i.e. span
  • A right BBB-module is equivalent to a (∗,B)(*,B)(∗,B)-bimodule, i.e. a span
Yeah, it's useful to think of modules as a special case of bimodules, and morphisms as a special case of spans.

But if you want to give the royal answer to

"what's a module of a monoid object in (Setop,×)(\mathsf{Set}^{\rm op}, \times)(Setop,×)?"

that is, the simplest, clearest answer, it's:

"a function".
There are lots of puzzles like this in category theory, where a fancy-sounding concept turns out to be something you already know. For such puzzles one always seeks the simplest answer.

Similarly, the royal answer to

"what's a bimodule between monoid objects in (Setop,×)(\mathsf{Set}^{\rm op}, \times)(Setop,×)?"

is

"a span of sets"

or perhaps even more clearly:

"a pair of functions with the same domain".

John Baez said:

But if you want to give the royal answer to

"what's a module of a monoid object in (Setop,×)(\mathsf{Set}^{\rm op}, \times)(Setop,×)?"

that is, the simplest, clearest answer, it's:

"a function".

That is a left module.

What is a right module of a monoid in (Setop,×)(\mathsf{Set^{op}},\times)(Setop,×)?
Also a function.
I didn't specify left or right modules because for a commutative monoid object there's a natural bijection between left and right modules.
So it doesn't make any difference in this particular question.
Ok. I wondered about that.

For noncommutative monoid objects it's necessary to say "left" or "right" module.... except in some other situations where you have a recipe to turn left modules into right modules and vice versa, which I don't want to get into.
But for commutative monoid objects it's rare to explicitly say whether the module is a left or right one. For example, nobody ever talks about "left vector spaces" and "right vector spaces".
Sure. That makes sense. Thank you.

Sometimes I work with "quaternionic vector spaces" - and then you gotta distinguish between left and right vector spaces! (They're just left or right H\mathbb{H}H-modules, but they act so much like vector spaces in some ways that it's tempting to call them quaternionic vector spaces.)
